quoteFirst: Deane nodded. It was, after all, perhaps the most sensible thing she could do to get clear away! "Send me my tea
quoteLast: ," he ordered, "and let me have a bath at once."
title: The Golden Web
author: Oppenheim, E. Phillips (Edward Phillips), 1866-1946; Kirkpatrick, William Arber-Brown, 1880- [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: As Wichita and King stepped out into the crisp, cool air of an Arizona night the voice of the sentry at the guard house rang out clearly against the silence: “Number One,
quoteLast: !” They paused to listen as the next sentry passed the call on: “Number Two, eight o’clock. All’s well!” Around the chain of sentries it went, fainter in the distance, growing again in volume to the final, “All’s well!” of Number One.
title: Apache devil
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice, 1875-1950

quoteFirst: Celeste took me up in her arms and ran with me down the carriage-way, not without having brought her pail and mine. We next called for a dozen more girls and boys at their houses.
quoteLast: we had got about a couple of miles from the place. Antoinette Leland suddenly screamed out, "Here he comes, here he comes!" "What comes?" cried they all.
title: Memoirs of a country doll. Written by herself

quoteFirst: To-morrow I must at all events be in the Prince's garden, where Roquairol at last gives his Tragedian. Come this evening--I implore thee by our love--

quoteFirst: Gordon opened his door a little way, and exclaimed in a testy and irritable tone, "Presently, presently." He made his regular appearance
quoteLast: , and no one ventured to again disturb him before the regulation hour.

author: Boulger, Demetrius Charles, 1853-1928

quoteFirst: Early this morning we set out on our journey again, it being moonshine and calm, and we feared lest the wind should change and become unfavourable to us if we stopped any longer. We all rowed as hard as possible, and happily arrived about
quoteLast: at Fort St. Frederic, which the English call Crown Point. Monsieur Lusignan, the governor, received us very politely.
title: Travels into North America, Volume 3 (of 3)
author: Kalm, Pehr, 1716-1779; Forster, Johann Reinhold, 1729-1798 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Same quarter. At 7 p.m. made sail under the Courses;
quoteLast: set the Topsails close reefed. At Noon, being in the Latitude of 47 degrees 43 minutes South, and Longitude East from Cape Saunders 2 degrees 10 minutes, wore and stood to the Northward.

quoteFirst: Keeping first in a westerly, and afterwards in a more south-westerly direction, through a rather uninteresting country, we arrived about
quoteLast: in a wide vale called Tákulum, full of rich succulent herbage and fine trees, where, it being supposed that we were out of danger, it was decided to give the horses and camels a feed after having watered them. I, for my part, was extremely thankful for getting a few hours’ rest in the shade of a venerable acacia, near the gentle slope surrounding the hollow.
title: Travels and discoveries in North and Central Africa

quoteFirst: Had the sea breeze set in, the strange ships would have been at anchor in the Bay by
quoteLast: , but the wind blowing out, they were driven by a strong lee current to the southward of the port. On the following day they re-appeared in their former situation, and a boat was sent to them, with a lieutenant of the navy in her, to offer assistance, and point out the necessary marks for entering the harbour.
title: A Narrative of the Expedition to Botany-Bay

quoteFirst: Isaac bethought him in haste of a capital scheme for removing Rosina to-morrow evening from the scene of operations. ‘You can get away to-morrow?’ he asked with a cunning leer. ‘About
quoteLast: at me house, Rosie?’

quoteLast: , and employed an hour and a half in passing the cascade, which was composed of two strong rapids. Immediately after this, two other rapids arrested our course. quoteLast: , and on this occasion sat in the gallery, which was quite wide enough to accommodate the members. It was proposed that I should take the chair, and I did so, and opened the proceedings by introducing rules to regulate the discussion.

quoteFirst: "How the devil did I happen to let
quoteLast: strike nine before I knew it?" muttered the visitor. He was at the drawing-room door as he concluded this self-addressed reproach, extending both hands toward the young woman who came from the fireplace to meet him.

quoteFirst: At the end of a week he began to grow impatient of the restraint, and, conceiving that no great danger would be incurred if he left his place of refuge in the darkness of night, he resolved to do so; moreover, he was destitute of money, and entertained some hope of being able to extort a sum from his unfortunate wife, whom he had driven to prostitution. Accordingly, at about
quoteLast: in the evening, he left the Vaults by means of the secret outlet before alluded to and gaining the street, proceeded at a rapid pace towards the Bowery. In the breast of his coat he carried a huge Bowie knife, with which to defend himself in case any attempt should be made to arrest him.
title: City Crimes; Or, Life in New York and Boston
author: Thompson, George, 1823-

quoteFirst: The only original Sagawa show on the road, remember!  Come early, gents, and bring your lady friends.  The doors of the big tent will open at
